xtiny-doc-page.author: Romain Guy
xtiny-doc-page.name: Options Dialog
xtiny-doc-page.title: Jext : Options
xtiny-doc-page.paragraph: The options dialog contains all the Jext settings. On the left part of the window is a tree which enables access the different settings categories. The right part contains the settings panel which changes when you click on a category in the tree on the left of the window. At the bottom there are three buttons: Save saves your settings, applies them and closes the window, Apply only saves and applies settings and Cancel closes the window.

submenu.title: General
submenu.item: This setting sets the console prompt. There are four default prompts: DOS, Linux, Jext and Solaris. Clicking one of these items will change the next setting content. See the Console section for more informations about prompts.
You can edit this field to customize the console prompt. Some examples are provided in the previous setting. See the Console section for more informations.
This setting allows you to set the maximum number of files shown in the menu File-Recents.
Sets the delay in seconds between each autosave. Used only when auto save is enabled.
Sets the directory in which Jext will look for templates files.
If the Jext loader server is enabled, using this option will cause arguments passed to Jext launching script to open files within a new window.
If you check this box, Jext displays the contents of the Dawn stack in the log window when a script exits. You should keep it checked if you write scripts.
If checked, Jext will automatically save all the opened files. The delay between each save can be set.
If this option is checked, Jext will automatically save the workspaces at the end of the session.

As new Jext versions are often released, you can ask Jext to check if a newer version has been released. If you check this setting, Jext will attempt to log onto its web site on startup. If the logon succeeds, and if a newer version is available, Jext displays a summary of the changes in the new version and displays the download URL.
Each time a command is entered, the console keeps it in memory. You can decide to save those commands from one session to the next by using this option.
This option causes Jext to display the full filename of the current file in the title bar.
On startup, Jext can display a tip in the bottom status bar. If checked a tip is also shown each time you Save/Apply options.
To increase the size of the text area, you can hide the left tabbed pane which contains the XTree.
You can also hide the top tabbed pane which contains the console.

submenu.title: Loading
submenu.item: You can make Jext load some classes on startup so that you don't need to wait for them to be loaded during execution.
If you disable the loading of the XInsert tool, startup will be much faster.
If you disable the loading of the Console tool, startup will be much faster.

submenu.title: User Interface
submenu.item: Jext now offers you the ability to select different UI skins. You'll find here the standard Swing ones, the Jext one(previously known as the "Jext UI theme") and, if installed, the Kunststoff and the ones for SkinLF(for this, one for each valid theme in <JextHome>\bin\themes). When you change skin and Apply or Save settings you'll see the new one(even if there could be some view problems until the restart).

Jext offers five different icon sets. Tiny is default icon set, the one you see the first time you launch Jext, Tiny Swing is the 16x16 Swing icons set, 20x20 is a well known icons set, Swing is the official Swing icons set and GNOME is a 24x24 GNOME style icons set.
Default Jext menus are flattened. Unchecking this option makes menus look like standard Swing ones.
Activates or deactivates the rollover effect in the toolbar.
Jext buttons are by default blue highlighted when the mouse moves over them. You can deactivate this behavior.
Activating this option will cause display of entitled menu separators for better visibility.
You can hide the toolbar by unchecking this box. You are advised to keep the toolbar visible.
This option displays a grayed toolbar when checked. Passing the mouse pointer over the buttons displays them in colors.

submenu.title: Editor
submenu.item: This settings defines how many lines Jext will scroll when you click on the topmost or bottom-most text area line.
Jext can highlight lines. If you enter 5 for instance, Jext will highlight every fifth line.
Enter the count of characters at which the wrap guide is to be placed.
This sets the character encoding used on save.
This option lets you choose the default editor font.
Sets the tabs size.
Allows you to select the syntax colorizing mode for the current file.
Defines the type of the line separator used on save.
Defines the split orientation when you activate the split editor option.
If checked, the text area is split so that you can edit two places in the same file. Note you can split/unsplit through the tools menu, the popup menu or the F6 key.
If checked, the interval highlight option will be used to highlight a line every x lines.
If checked, the wrap guide will be shown within the text area.
Displays a block caret.
Makes the caret blink.
If you select this option, the line with caret on it is highlighted.
If you select this option, end of lines are marked with a dot.
This option activates auto indent on TAB press.
This option activates auto indent on ENTER press.
Using this option inserts spaces instead of a tab character when you press TAB.
Enables the use of tab stops.

By default HOME and END keys simply put your caret on start and end of the line. This option improves upon this behaviour. Pressing HOME once puts the caret on the beginning of the line, press it twice and the caret is put on beginning of the current page, press it a third time and the caret goes to beginning of the document.
If checked, Jext will use the directory which contains the current editing file as the default directory in open and save dialogs.
If you use find or replace dialog and if some text is selected in the text area, this text will be automatically used as search pattern.
This option makes the C+Left or C+Right keystrokes skip together a word and the space after it.

submenu.title: Print
submenu.item: Selects the default font used for printing.
Prints the line number in front of each printed line of text.
Prints the header (file name...).
Prints the footer. Available for colorized printing only.
Print colors and styles.
Sets the printing layout. Available in non-colorized printing only.

submenu.title: Gutter
submenu.item: When you expand the gutter, this settings defines the default width of the gutter.
Defines the width of the gutter border.
In the gutter, lines numbers are highlighted. Here you can set the interval between each highlight.
You can display lines numbers on left, right or center of the gutter.
Let you choose the font used to display lines numbers.
If checked, relieves you from having to double click the gutter border each for each file to expand it.
Enables/disables lines numbering in the gutter.

submenu.title: Colors & Styles
submenu.item: In this settings panel, you can change the color of many Jext interface elements. You can also modify the syntax colorizing modes colors.

submenu.title: Shortcuts
submenu.item: You can define the shortcut for each menu item within Jext, even plugins menu items. Simply double click on the shortcut cell in front of a menu item and type in the new shortcut. Then press ENTER to set the shortcut.

submenu.title: Filter
submenu.item: Jext can select the appropriate syntax colorizing mode when you open a file. For that, it uses file filters which can be changed in this panel. To edit a filter, simply double click it. Filters are Un*x glob filters. Press ENTER to set the filter.

submenu.title: Language
submenu.item: You can change the language used by Jext. Simply select one from the list, save the options and restart Jext.

submenu.title: Security
submenu.item: Jext uses a small server to open all its instances in the same JVM to save memory. Yet, this server opens a secure door to the external computers. If you are connected to a network and do not trust Jext security (which is quite strong), you should disable this option. Note that Jext will warn you if anybody attempts to break into your system through the Jext server.

menu.title: Plugins Options
menu.item: Each plugin can add its own settings panel or even several panels. In this last case, a new node appears in the list.
